description: The Network+ certification was introduced by CompTIA in 1999 and was designed to do for Network Technicians what the A+ certification did for Computer Technicians. Obtaining Network+ certification shows that the holder possess the same knowledge and skills of someone who has worked for nine months as a Network Technician. The Network+ exam covers topics ranging from theory (terminology, topology and design) to hardware (routers, switches and cabling) and provides users with a broad, vendor neutral perspective on the topics required to work in the field of Network Administration.
descriptionMD: The Network+ certification was introduced by CompTIA in 1999 and was designed to do for Network Technicians what the A+ certification did for Computer Technicians. Obtaining Network+ certification shows that the holder possess the same knowledge and skills of someone who has worked for nine months as a Network Technician. The Network+ exam covers topics ranging from theory (terminology, topology and design) to hardware (routers, switches and cabling) and provides users with a broad, vendor neutral perspective on the topics required to work in the field of Network Administration. __This course has been CAQC'd and qualifies for CEU credits. [Click here](https://itpro.tv/comptia-partnership) to get an exam voucher discount.__
name: CompTIA Network+ 2016
subtitle: Vendor-neutral networking

episodes.description: The Network+ certification was introduced by CompTIA in 1999 and was designed to do for Network Technicians what the A+ certification did for Computer Technicians. Obtaining Network+ certification shows that the holder possess the same knowledge and skills of someone who has worked for nine months as a Network Technician. The Network+ exam covers topics ranging from theory (terminology, topology and design) to hardware (routers, switches and cabling) and provides users with a broad, vendor neutral perspective on the topics required to work in the field of Network Administration.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:03.620 --> 00:00:04.771
[SOUND] In this series,

2

we're going to be looking at CompTIA's
Network+ (N10-006) certification exam.

3

Now this exam centers around
networking technologies,

4

wireless technologies as
well as wired technologies.

5

And when you are through with
taking this certification exam,

6

it does demonstrate competencies in things
like network design, basic connectivity.

7

We'll look at things like an understanding
of maintaining network documentation,

8
00:00:30.350 --> 00:00:33.070
as well as the limitations,
the weaknesses and

9

implementation of security standards and
protocols.

10
00:00:36.500 --> 00:00:39.190
One of the things to keep in mind
is that the candidate will have

11

a basic understanding of
the emerging technologies,

12

like things like cloud-based
technologies and unified communication.

13

Let's go ahead and took a look at what the
breakdown of what this exam will be, so

14

you can kinda get an idea as to what you
can expect when you look at the series.

15
00:00:54.550 --> 00:00:58.300
You'll see that in 1.0, we're gonna be
talking about, well, network architecture.

16
00:00:58.300 --> 00:01:02.090
You could see that that is
22% of the overall exam.

17
00:01:02.090 --> 00:01:03.840
You could see here that in Domain 2.0,

18
00:01:03.840 --> 00:01:06.680
we're gonna be looking
at network operations.

19
00:01:06.680 --> 00:01:09.480
You could see that that is pretty
hefty portion of the exam as well,

20
00:01:09.480 --> 00:01:12.240
you can see that it is 20% of your exam.

21
00:01:12.240 --> 00:01:14.260
We'll also be looking at network security,

22
00:01:14.260 --> 00:01:17.590
very important to keep your network
secure cuz when you bring them online,

23
00:01:17.590 --> 00:01:21.960
we gotta make sure that they stay online
and they don't get attacked or hacked.

24
00:01:21.960 --> 00:01:23.970
We're also gonna look
at troubleshooting and

25
00:01:23.970 --> 00:01:29.130
you can see that out of everything
within the exam breakdown here, 24%,

26
00:01:29.130 --> 00:01:34.080
troubleshooting does constitute
the majority of this entire exam.

27
00:01:34.080 --> 00:01:38.876
Finally, we're gonna talk a little about
these industry-wide standards inside of

28
00:01:38.876 --> 00:01:40.950
networking communications today.

29
00:01:40.950 --> 00:01:44.380
Going a little bit farther than that,
if we break down some of the things that

30
00:01:44.380 --> 00:01:46.480
you can see when we look
at network architecture,

31
00:01:46.480 --> 00:01:49.730
we'll be looking at the various
connectivity devices that are in our

32
00:01:49.730 --> 00:01:53.780
networks that move communications
from source to destination.

33
00:01:53.780 --> 00:01:56.530
We'll also be looking at
the different various services

34
00:01:56.530 --> 00:01:58.660
that allow our networks to communicate.

35
00:01:58.660 --> 00:02:00.720
We'll be looking at services like DHCP.

36
00:02:00.720 --> 00:02:02.880
You can see DNS as well.

37
00:02:02.880 --> 00:02:05.830
We'll be looking at different forms
of things like network translation

38
00:02:05.830 --> 00:02:06.970
technologies.

39
00:02:06.970 --> 00:02:12.730
We will be looking at copper media, fiber
media, wireless communications and more.

40
00:02:12.730 --> 00:02:17.710
So you can say that there is a lot of
information that is going to be in this

41
00:02:17.710 --> 00:02:19.230
certification exam.

42
00:02:19.230 --> 00:02:22.060
So let's go ahead and
let's bump on over the CompTIA's website.

43
00:02:22.060 --> 00:02:25.160
Now, if you want more information
about what you can expect,

44
00:02:25.160 --> 00:02:27.990
the objective as well as the exam details,

45
00:02:27.990 --> 00:02:32.510
you can always go to www.comptia.org and
you could find this information.

46
00:02:32.510 --> 00:02:36.928
You can see that the current
Exam Code is N10-006.

47
00:02:36.928 --> 00:02:41.573
And you can see here too, Network+ covers
the configuration, management, and

48
00:02:41.573 --> 00:02:45.620
troubleshooting of common wireless and
wired network devices.

49
00:02:45.620 --> 00:02:49.640
The number of questions that you can see
inside of this exam is going to be, well,

50
00:02:49.640 --> 00:02:52.660
90 questions, maximum of 90 questions.

51
00:02:52.660 --> 00:02:55.500
Now the type of questions,
they're multiple choice, right?

52
00:02:55.500 --> 00:02:58.830
Multiple choice questions, right,
the fact that you're gonna pick A,

53
00:02:58.830 --> 00:03:03.580
B, C, or D, you'll also see things
like multiple answers, right?

54
00:03:03.580 --> 00:03:06.190
You see single and multiple responses.

55
00:03:06.190 --> 00:03:10.390
For instance, if you have a question and
it requires multiple responses,

56
00:03:10.390 --> 00:03:13.580
it might say something like,
well choose two, maybe A and B.

57
00:03:13.580 --> 00:03:17.950
You will also have things
like drag-and-drops.

58
00:03:17.950 --> 00:03:22.230
A list of potential answers on one side
that you have to drag them and enter and

59
00:03:22.230 --> 00:03:24.440
fill out boxes on the right side.

60
00:03:24.440 --> 00:03:26.820
They also talk about
performance based questions.

61
00:03:26.820 --> 00:03:29.760
Performance based questions means you
do have the potential to see some

62
00:03:29.760 --> 00:03:32.950
simulations on the CompTIA Net+ exam.

63
00:03:32.950 --> 00:03:35.850
You can see that the length
of the test is 90 minutes.

64
00:03:35.850 --> 00:03:41.796
You see that the passing score
is 720 on a scale of 100-900.

65
00:03:41.796 --> 00:03:45.900
The experiment, or experience,
excuse me, recommended experiences,

66
00:03:45.900 --> 00:03:50.936
well they rather recommend having the A+
certification, taking the 901 and

67
00:03:50.936 --> 00:03:56.950
the 902 currently in those exams, and also
to have nine months of network experience.

68
00:03:56.950 --> 00:04:01.030
We do have a few different language types
if that is something that you need.

69
00:04:01.030 --> 00:04:03.670
Keep in mind that the series is
going to be based in English,

70
00:04:03.670 --> 00:04:08.740
but there is a Japanese version and
a German version as well.

71
00:04:10.530 --> 00:04:14.932
Last but not least,
you can see that the overall price for

72
00:04:14.932 --> 00:04:20.448
the Network+ (N10-006) exam
is going to be $294.00.

73
00:04:20.448 --> 00:04:24.446
So if network is something that you
believe you want to accomplish,

74
00:04:24.446 --> 00:04:27.602
whether it is a certification exam or
whether it is for

75
00:04:27.602 --> 00:04:31.462
self experience in a real world to
maybe give you a better position

76
00:04:31.462 --> 00:04:34.926
within your company,
then this is what you've gotta be.

77
00:04:34.926 --> 00:04:41.790
So stick around as we got a lot more at
CompTIA Network+ (N10-006) coming up.

78
00:04:41.790 --> 00:04:45.642
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain the functions and applications of various network devices such as Routers, Switches, Multilayer Switches, Firewalls, Hardware and Software based Intrusion Detection/Prevention Systems(IDS/IPS), and Access Points.
episodes.title: Network Devices

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue explaining the functions and applications of various network devices such as Content Filters, Load Balancers, Hubs, Analog Modems, Packet Shapers, and VPN Concentrators.
episodes.title: Network Devices Part 2

episodes.description: This show covers quite a deluge of underpinning protocols used to offer network services and apllications. Wes and Cherokee introduce the term Virtual Private Network (VPN), explain why and how one would choose to use one in addition to several tunneling protocols.
episodes.title: Network Services and Applications

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Cherokee provide a brief review of the protocols mentioned in the previous episode. You will also see an in depth description of how Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service (RADIUS) can be useful for securing your network whilst still allowing remote users access to your network resources.
episodes.title: Network Services and Applications Part 2

episodes.description: This episode really focuses on Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP). You will see how and why DHCP is considered one of the core network services. Wes demonstrates how to configure the scope, where you would set reservations and the available scope options.
episodes.title: Install and Configure Services and Applications

episodes.description: This episode picks up from the previous episode in which Cherokee and Wes are covering Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP). Specifically, you will see how the underpinning protocol relate to the client.
episodes.title: Install and Config Services and Applications Pt 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes continue with installing and configuring network services DNS, Domain Name System.  Wes explains the purpose and shows the DNS process using a DNS Server and understanding the DNS Hierarchy found on the backbone of the internet.  He demonstrates creating A records and CNAME records to show us how the DNS database stores the records and uses the records for resolution.
episodes.title: Install and Config Services and Applications Pt 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes continue with explaining the nature of different services.  Wes begins with some additional records for DNS, showing the creation of MX and NS records in the DNS Database.   He moves to the describe the functioning of a proxy server  and why we would choose to use it.  Along with this is the use of NAT —SNAT, PAT, DNAT.  He describes when to use each of the different types of network address translation.
episodes.title: Install and Config Services and Applications Pt 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes introduce some of the common WAN technologies networking Professionals will encounter in the field and some of them they won’t.  Some of the technologies are considered legacy technologies from the past.  They talk about the specifications and where you tend to find them in the used.  They describe Frame Relay, Satellite Networking and ISDN.
episodes.title: WAN Technologies

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike explain the characteristics and benefits of various WAN technologies. They discuss ATM, PPP and multilink PPP and MPLS.
episodes.title: WAN Technologies Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their discussion on various WAN technologies. They talk about leased lines and various protocols used. They also describe GSM, CDMA, WiMAX and more.
episodes.title: WAN Technologies Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike discuss installing and terminating various cable types and connectors. They demonstrate terminating UTP with an RJ-45 connector. They describe various copper and fiber connectors. They also look at different copper and fiber cable types.
episodes.title: Cable Types, Connectors and Tools

episodes.description: This episode is a continuation where you will see different types of cables and connectors. First, Wes explains an F connector and recaps what was covered in the previous episode. You will also see another type of copper media, twisted pair cabling and its many variations.
episodes.title: Cable Types, Connectors and Tools Part 2

episodes.description: In the previous episode Wes and Cherokee discussed different physical attributes of twisted pair cabling. This episode focuses more on the wiring schematic options or the "pin outs". By changing the order of the individual wires you can manipulate the cables electrical properties to accommodate your environment. Specifically you will se a straight, crossover and rollover cable.
episodes.title: Cable Types, Connectors and Tools Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode Wes sheds some light on fiber optic cabling. First, you will see different examples of connector types. Next you will learn the difference between single and multimode cables as well as adapters and converters.
episodes.title: Cable Types, Connectors and Tools Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes help you differentiate between the different network topologies. They show you topologies like Mesh (full/partial), Bus, Ring (Token/FDDI), Star, Hybrid, Point-to-Point, and Point-to-Multipoint.
episodes.title: Common Network Topologies

episodes.description: In this show Wes and Cherokee cover numerous terms to really define the style of your network. First, the talk about all the different types of "ANs" such as wide area network (WAN) local area network (LAN) and more. You will also see how to use the proper terminology when describing a wireless network.
episodes.title: Network Infrastructure Implementations

episodes.description: This episode Wes and Cherokee continue to discuss different types of available networks. They begin with personal area network (PAN). Next they explain different types of short range wireless technologies. Lastly, supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) networks are described followed with a breakdown of the term medianet.
episodes.title: Network Infrastructure Implementations Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes begin looking at the particulars of implementing and configuring IP addresses and schemas. Here they start at the beginning by explaining the basics of what an IP version 4 address looks like, how it works, and the different parts that make it up. They also explore Classful IP addressing.
episodes.title: Implement and Configure Addressing Schemas

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue looking at the particulars of implementing and configuring IP addresses and schemas. Here they take a closer look at IP addresses and subnet masks by converting from decimal to binary and vice versa. They also begin to break down subnet masks and Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) notation.
episodes.title: Implement and Configure Addressing Schemas Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue looking at the particulars of implementing and configuring IP addresses and schemas. Here they discuss the technique of filtering an IP address through its subnet mask through the process of "Bitwise ANDing". Then they tackle the arduous topic of Subnetting.
episodes.title: Implement and Configure Addressing Schemas Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue looking at the particulars of implementing and configuring IP addresses and schemas. Here they discuss Public vs. Private IP addresses, Network Address Translation(NAT), Port Address Translation(PAT), multicast, broadcast, and unicast traffic, as well as Broadcast and Collision Domains.
episodes.title: Implement and Configure Addressing Schemas Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes finish looking at the particulars of implementing and configuring IP addresses and schemas. Here they talk about Media Access Control(MAC) addresses then move right into the next iteration of the Internet Protocol, IPv6. They discuss IPv6 address structure and compression as well as tunneling from IPv6 to IPv4 networks and vice versa.
episodes.title: Implement and Configure Addressing Schemas Part 5

episodes.description: In this episode Cherokee and Wes introduce the fundamentals of routing. You will see protocols explained so you can understand when and why one one may be used over another. Additionally, one would also want to know how to categorize a routing protocol as distance vector or link state.
episodes.title: Routing Concepts and Protocol Basics

episodes.description: This is a continuation where Wes and Cherokee continue explaining routing concepts and protocol basics. Wes begins by explaining concepts such as the loopback interface, routing loops, and the default route. Next, autonomous numbers  are explained followed by route redistribution, high availability, route aggregation and routing metrics used to determine the best route.
episodes.title: Routing Concepts and Protocol Basics Part 2

episodes.description: In this show Wes and Cherokee discuss what the concept of unified communications really means. Wes explains what components, services and protocols make up this unified way of communicating. Protocols such as QOS, Cos, H.323, SDP, SIP and RTP should all be understood prior to taking the N10-006 exam.
episodes.title: Unified Communication Basics

episodes.description: In this show you will hear Wes Cherokee explain what virtualization is, how it can be implemented, how it relates to cloud computing and a look at different cloud offerings. Wes also illustrates what a storage area network (SAN) is and how it differs from a network attached storage device (NAS).
episodes.title: Cloud and Virtualization

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Wes explain why and how a Storage Area Network (SAN) would be used. They also discuss a variety of cloud solutions. Tune in to learn the fundamental concepts and terms surrounding these technologies.
episodes.title: Cloud and Virtualization Part 2

episodes.description: If you were asked to design a network where would you start? Wes and Cherokee detail important factors and considerations to keep in mind during the planning of a network. Interviewing the customer in addition to performing site surveys are required to understand all needs such as budget, timeframe, regulatory compliancies, compatibility, environmental factors and more.
episodes.title: Implement a Basic Network

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes dive into the exciting world of network monitoring tools. They start by looking at the function and purpose of Packet Analyzers aka Packet Sniffers. Then they move onto exploring Interface Monitoring tools like Solar Winds and Netstat. Finally, they discuss Port Scanners such as Nmap for host discovery and service enumeration.
episodes.title: Monitoring Tools

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue looking at different types of network monitoring tools. They begin by talking about SNMP management software where you'll learn about Traps, Get, Walk, and MIBS. They also discuss some of the security concerns regarding SNMP. They also explore Packet Flow monitoring, Syslogs, SIEM devices, and wireless survey tools.
episodes.title: Monitoring Tools Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore analyzing metrics and reports from monitoring and tracking performance tools. They start by setting a performance baseline using the Performance Monitor in the Windows operating system. They look at data like network, memory, cpu, and disk utilization, taking a "snapshot" of that for future reference.
episodes.title: Analyzing Metrics and Reports

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue to explore analyzing metrics and reports from monitoring and tracking performance tools. They pick back up by looking at Log Management through utilities like the Event Viewer or Syslog. They also explore Graphing utilities such as the Reliability Monitor. Finally, they examine monitoring network interface monitoring and link status.
episodes.title: Analyzing Metrics and Reports Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain using appropriate resources to support configuration management. They spend the entirety of the this show exploring the use of backups. They discuss the types and uses of backups in a network environment and even demonstrate taking a backup using the Windows Server backup utility.
episodes.title: Supporting Configuration Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue to explain using appropriate resources to support configuration management. Here they discuss on-boarding and off-boarding mobile devices, the use of Network Access Control(NAC) systems, and the importance of documenting the physical and logical network, assets, IP Address utilization, and vendor information.
episodes.title: Supporting Configuration Management Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes dive into the importance of network segmentation. They then look at some of the instances that may lend itself to a segmented network. This includes, SCADA, legacy systems, public/private networks, network optimization, and testing labs.
episodes.title: Importance of Network Segmentation

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore installing and applying patches and updates. They begin by discussing good patch management procedures and then demonstrate installing a firmware update to a Linksys router. Then they look at installing driver updates and configuration backup.
episodes.title: Install and Apply Patches and Updates

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie cover various topics and concepts related to switch configuration. They explain the basic functionality of switches inside of our networks, the difference between a managed and unmanaged switches. They will demonstrate the first steps of configuring the switch.
episodes.title: Configure a Switch

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie continue their coverage of various topics and concepts related to switch configuration. They demonstrate setting up an IP address on the switch for management purposes, setting administrative passwords, and performing remote management through technologies such as Telnet, SSH, terminal and Putty. They also talk about setting up AAA or authentication, authorization and accounting as well.
episodes.title: Configure a Switch Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie continue their coverage of various topics and concepts related to switch configuration. They talk about trunking through 802.1Q, ISL as wells port mirroring or bonding and virtual local area networks or VLANs
episodes.title: Configure a Switch Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie continue their coverage of various topics and concepts related to switch configuration. They go deeper into the concept of VLANs and default or native VLAN. They will also discuss other topics like the Virtual Trunking Protocol or VTP and more.
episodes.title: Configure a Switch Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie continue their coverage of various topics and concepts related to switch configuration. They dive into the technology used within a switched network to combat broadcast storms and forwarding loops call the Spanning Tree Algorithm.
episodes.title: Configure a Switch Part 5

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain how to install and configure wireless LAN infrastructures and implement the appropriate technologies in support of wireless capable devices. Specific topics covered here include: SOHO Access Points, VLAN Pooling, Site Surveys/Heat Maps, Wireless Frequencies, and Goodput.
episodes.title: Configure and Implement WLAN Infrastructure

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue explaining how to install and configure wireless LAN infrastructures and implement the appropriate technologies in support of wireless capable devices. Specific topics covered here include: Wireless Topologies, SSIDs, Antenna types, MIMO/MUMIMO, and Signal Strength.
episodes.title: Configure and Implement WLAN Infrastructure Part 2

episodes.description: Risk spares no network and should be adequately understood to execute preemptive actions. Wes and Cherokee stress the importance having a Disaster Recovery Plan (DRP). Wes describes backup implementations such as hot, warm, and cold sites. They also discuss several other options when it comes to disaster recovery.
episodes.title: Risk Concepts

episodes.description: What is a data breach? What happens if or when one occurs? Cherokee and Wes answer these questions and more. Knowing your critical assets is essential so you can sufficiently prepare. Also covered in this show are the differences between vulnerability scanning and penetration testing.
episodes.title: Risk Concepts Part 2

episodes.description: Wes and Cherokee explain the numerous styles of Denial of Service attacks (DOS). They remind us to  think outside the box when clasifying these attacks. They also explain the weaknesses within address resolution protocol (arp).
episodes.title: Vulnerabilities and Threats

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Cherokee explain several vulnerabilities associated with wireless networks. Wes explains the difference between a rogue AP vs an evil twin. War driving and chalking are also defined. Followed by bluetooth vulnerabilities such as bluejacking and bluesnarfing. Lastly, WEP, WPA, and WPA2 are covered.
episodes.title: Vulnerabilities and Threats Part 2

episodes.description: This is a continuation of  a conversation where Wes and Cherokee look at several threats. Next, they then examine vulnerabilities specifically called out on the CompTIA objective list. Finally, Wes provides a list of insecure protocols followed by secure replacement suggestions.
episodes.title: Vulnerabilities and Threats Part 3

episodes.description: Watch Wes and Cherokee discuss different methods to harden, or strengthen the security of a particular network component. Anti-malware implementations, MAC address filtering,  V-LANS assignments and security policies are just a few you will see covered in this show.
episodes.title: Implement Hardening Techniques

episodes.description: This is a continuation where Cherokee and Wes explore additional hardening techniques. First, Wes compares and contrasts insecure protocols. He then covers additional components associated with IPSec. Lastly, they explain the role access control lists (ACLs) have on our networks.
episodes.title: Implement Hardening Techniques Part 2

episodes.description: This is a part three where Wes and Cherokee discuss wireless security and associated technologies so one can make decisions to help harden a wireless infrastructure. They also explain different methods of authentication. Lastly, Wes reminds us of different hash algorithms.
episodes.title: Implement Hardening Techniques Part 3

episodes.description: One could implement a plethora of technical and administrative security controls however it is import include physical security controls to have a good balance. Wes and Cherokee discuss several options available. First, they look at different types of security cameras. Next,  they explore different types of door locks and even discuss hiring a security guard.
episodes.title: Physical Security Controls

episodes.description: With the numerous options and features of firewalls choosing one can sometimes prove to be difficult. Wes and Cherokee aim to clarify these different offerings so you can choose the best solution for your needs. They discuss several aspects to consider including but not limited to the logical network placement, host vs network firewalls, stateful vs stateless and how those features correlate with the layers of the OSI model.
episodes.title: Basic Firewall

episodes.description: In this show Wes and Cherokee look at different ways one can limit and manage access granted to network resources. Wes explains 802.1x, posture assessment, guest networks, quarantine networks, and edge vs access control. Lastly, Wes shows a demonstration of how a network policy server can limit access based on preconfigured parameters.
episodes.title: Network Access Control Models

episodes.description: Watch Wes and Cherokee explain the basic forensic process to help ease any confusion and help increase the odds of obtaining good usable evidence to be presented in a court of law. Tune in to see several factors that ultimately impact the forensic report that is generated during an investigation.
episodes.title: Basic Forensic Concepts

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Cherokee explain how to methodically approach problems within your environment by using CompTIA's Network Troubleshooting model. They walk thru each step and give examples to help you become a successful troubleshooter.
episodes.title: Network Troubleshooting Model

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore a few network troubleshooting tools; analyzing and interpreting their output. They start by taking an in-depth look at ipconfig, ifconfig, and netstat which are used to look at network connections and connectivity issues.
episodes.title: Output of Troubleshooting Tools

episodes.description: In this episode Cherokee and Wes explore command-line based troubleshooting tools. They demonstrate ping and the many ways this connectivity tool help help pinpoint an issue. Next, they look at address resolution protocol (ARP) and explain the uses and dangers of this protocol.
episodes.title: Output of Troubleshooting Tools Part 2

episodes.description: This is a continuation episode where Wes and Cherokee continue to examine troubleshhoting tools. Specifically you will see tracert/traceroutre,  nslookup, dig, pathping, a mac address lookup table . Next, they show physical tools such as a line tester, fox and hound, cable certifier, and multimeter.
episodes.title: Output of Troubleshooting Tools Part 3

episodes.description: When you introduce wireless connectivity in your network you introduce the possibility of various issues. Join Wes and Cherokee as they discuss issues such as signal loss, interference, access point placement, and mismatched channels. Tune in to learn of several other problems you may encounter.
episodes.title: Resolve Common Wireless Issues

episodes.description: Cherokee and Wes continue to discuss problems you may encounter within your wireless environments. You will also see them explain the several iterations of the 802.11 standards.
episodes.title: Resolve Common Wireless Issues Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes help you to troubleshoot and resolve common copper cable issues. Issues covered include shorts in the cable, Opens Impedance Mismatches, Incorrect Termination, Cross-Talk, and Attenuation. They also demonstrate the use of a cable tester to verify cable type and/or integrity.
episodes.title: Common Copper Issues

episodes.description: Watch this show to uncover and resolve common fiber issues with Cherokee and Wes. Being aware of issues such as attenuation, wavelength mismatch, distance and bend radius limitations can help you become more effective when troubleshooting or performing maintenance.
episodes.title: Resolve Common Fiber Issues

episodes.description: When it comes to network troubleshooting there is quite a range of potential problems. Cherokee and Wes begin explaining what type of issues one may face. They begin looking at incorrect IP configuration/default gateway configurations, broadcast storms, switching loops, duplicate IP addresses, end-to-end connectivity, and DHCP configurations.
episodes.title: Common Network Issues

episodes.description: In this show Cherokee and Wes continue to examine common network issues you may encounter. Wes spends a good amount of time discussing Domain Name System problems. He demonstrates how to maneuver both through the GUI and command line interface to resolve these problems.
episodes.title: Common Network Issues Part 2

episodes.description: Wes and Cherokee continue their conversation by discussing how cable placement, simultaneous wired and wireless connections, power failures and more can effect communication quality. Wes then demonstrates how underpinning technologies such as Network and Discovery can effect functionality of other technologies if disabled or misconfigured.
episodes.title: Common Network Issues Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike discuss resolving common security issues. They talk about misconfiguration issues with routers, firewalls, and applications. They also look at malware, ICMP issues, malicious users and authentication issues.
episodes.title: Resolve Common Security Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their look at resolving common security issues. They demonstrate misconfigured ACL issues, scanning a system to determine open ports, running Windows Defender, banner grabbing and more.
episodes.title: Resolve Common Security Issues Part 2

episodes.description: In this show Cherokee and Wes shift gears by exploring wide area network (WAN) issues. They talk about things like loss of internet connectivity, interface errors, and even revisit the concept of split horizon. They also cover some DNS and router configuration problems. Customer premise equipment is not overlooked followed by latency issues such as throttling and satellite.
episodes.title: Resolve Common WAN Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore and explain the venerable Open Systems Interconnect(OSI) model's 7 layers. They take you through each of the layers explaining the purpose and function of each which helps you understand the common communications framework that modern networks utilize.
episodes.title: OSI Model

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes round out their discussion of the OSI model for network communications. Here they explain the details of the processing order of datagrams on a network as well as the encapsulation/de-encapsulation process.
episodes.title: OSI Model Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes walk you through some of the fundamentally basic network concepts and theories. They explain the process of encapsulation and de-encapsulation and modulation techniques like multiplexing. Other topics covered include broadband and baseband defined, sampling, and bit/baud rates.
episodes.title: Basics of Network Theory and Concepts

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes round out their conversation about basic network concepts and theories by discussing Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Avoidance(CSMA/CA), 802.11 RTS/CTS, and the TCP/IP networking model in contrast to the OSI model.
episodes.title: Basics of Network Theory and Concepts Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore the myriad of wired connectivity standards that you'll need to know for the CompTIA Network+ exam. These standards include the major copper wire standards of past and present such as 10Base2, 10Base5, 10BaseT, 100BaseT, and 1000BaseT.
episodes.title: Wired Connectivity Standards

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue looking at wired connectivity standards, here picking back up with Optical Cabling. The walk you through each of the different Fiber technologies found on the Network+ exam, such as 10GBaseSR, 10GBaseER, and 10GBaseSW. They also discuss broadband standards like DOCSIS.
episodes.title: Wired Connectivity Standards Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode you will hear Wes and Cherokee cover several examples of policies you may encounter. Be prepared to know the differences between policies such as Service Level Agreement (SLA), Memorandum of Understanding (MOW), Master Service agreement (MSA) and Statement of Work (SOW) before taking the Network+ exam.
episodes.title: Implement Policies and Procedures

episodes.description: Safety should always be considered when working around electronics. Cherokee and Wes explain several safety practices to follow to maintain a safe environment. Concerns range from electrical safety to fire suppression systems. Tune in now to learn more!
episodes.title: Summarize Safety Practices

episodes.description: In this show Cherokee and Wes discuss some installation best practices. They begin by looking at how to wire a building that adheres to structured wiring standards. Next, they explain additional tips such as power management techniques, cable trays and sever racks.
episodes.title: Installation Best Practices

episodes.description: Wes and Cherokee continue a previous discussion surrounding installation best practices. They explain the importance  choosing a proper rack mount, labeling cabling, rack monitoring systems, and rack security systems.
episodes.title: Installation Best Practices Part 2

episodes.description: Implementing changes on the fly or without following a proper procedure can wreak havoc on an organization.  Wes and Cherokee share some tips to help facilitate change management. Wes shows us where we can obtain templates to help us create change request forms and get those submitted through a formal approval process.
episodes.title: Change Management Procedures

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes discuss configuring and applying different ports and protocols. Ports and protocols covered include FTP, SNMP, SSH, Telnet, DNS, and DHCP.
episodes.title: Compare and Configure Ports and Protocols

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes discuss configuring and applying different ports and protocols. Ports and protocols covered include SMB, RDP, HTTP/S, POP, IMAP, MGCP, TFTP, SIP, RTP, H.323, and SMTP.
episodes.title: Compare and Configure Ports and Protocols Part 2

topics.title: Industry standards, practices, and network theory
